Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Harnessing the Power of Herbaria to Understand the Changing Flora of California: A Biodiversity Hotspot in Peril
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to compile and provide information (e.g., species name, location, habitat, and flowering time) from California-collected vascular plant specimens held at 19 herbaria in California and at Harvard University (repository of many older California specimens). The plants targeted are those that dominate California habitats and those most imperiled by threats to biodiversity (including climate change). Specimen information will be available online at the Consortium of California Herbaria (CCH) Web portal (http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/consortium). The project will also accomplish the seamless provision of data on California plants held by the museums of SEINet (Southwest Environmental Information Network) via the CCH web site as a step toward building regional and national consortia.

This project provides tangible benefits to the public, students of all levels, and the research community. Specimen data will be downloadable so that anyone can use the information to pursue interests and questions (e.g., understanding current plant distributions, identifying plants of a particular place, predicting future plant migrations). Undergraduate students will be involved extensively with data entry, providing them with skills and training applicable to future professional pursuits. This project is a major step toward building a United States virtual plant museum that provides information on the distribution of plants nationwide.

The images and digitized data from this project will be integrated into the online national resource as outlined in the community strategic plan available at http://digbiocol.files.wordpress.com/2010/05/digistratplanfinaldraft.pdf.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to make available digital information (e.g., species name, location, habitat, flowering time) from California-collected vascular plant specimens held at 19 herbaria in California and at Harvard University (a repository of many older California specimens).  This included databasing over 338,600 specimens of California plants and adding geographic coordinates to over 500,000 specimens. The plants targeted were those that dominate California habitats (i.e., woody plants and grasses) and those most imperiled by threats to biodiversity, including climate change (i.e., alpine plants and those listed by the California Native Plant Society as of conservation concern).

            As part of the overall project, UC Berkeley managed the northern node, comprised of 6 institutions: University and Jepson Herbaria, UC Berkeley; Chico State University; Harvard Herbaria; Humboldt State University; San Jose State University; and UC Santa Cruz.  All partners reached their goal for databasing and collectively, the partners in the northern node exceeded the georeferencing goal for the grant.

            Specimen information has been made freely available online at the Consortium of California Herbaria (CCH) Web portal (http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/consortium). The project also accomplished the seamless provision of data on California plants held by the museums of SEINet (Southwest Environmental Information Network) via the CCH web site as a step toward building regional and national consortia.  In addition, CCH records are published to iDigBio and GBIF and automatic updates are sent monthly.  Records are also shared with Calflora, which provides information on wild California plants for conservation, education, and appreciation; Calscape, a partnership between the Jepson Herbarium and the California Native Plant Society focusing on providing information about native plants used in gardens and small scale restoration projects; and the Flora of Baja California web site, which allows users to search nearly 93,000 specimen records.

            Undergraduate students carried out most of the work, and thus the grant funds did double-duty in generating the needed data while also training students.  The students had the opportunity to gain experience in spatial referencing techniques, database interfaces, and recognize the importance and necessity of accuracy in their work. All of these are important skills that help build their experience base and better prepare them for opportunities beyond their current student status.

            This project provides tangible benefits to the public, students of all levels, and the research community. The specimen data can be used by anyone to pursue interests and questions (e.g., understanding current plant distributions, identifying plants of a particular place, predicting future plant migrations).  The CCH is widely used in research; with 1,229 literature citations since 2012 (according to Google Scholar).  For example, ecologists have used our data to make taxon distribution models to predict climate change.  Plant pathologists have used our data and specimens to track diseases such as sudden oak death.  There is a broad use of CCH in areas outside of academia as well, including land management, conservation planning, weed management, native plant gardening, and environmental consulting.
